data.question: What are the two types of Ln(II)−Co4 isocarbonyl polymeric arrays prepared?
What reaction conditions were used to synthesize {(Et2O)3Ln[Co4(CO)11]}∞ (1, Ln = Yb; 2, Ln = Eu)?
data.answer: Transmetalation reactions involving 1:2 molar ratios of Ln metal (Ln = Yb, Eu) and Hg[Co(CO)4]2 in Et2O

data.question: What is the symmetry of the [Co4(CO)11]2- cluster in {(Et2O)3-x(THF)xLn[Co4(CO)11]}∞ (1−3)?
data.answer: Pseudo C3v symmetry

data.question: What is the role of diethyl ether in the formation of [Co4(CO)11]2- clusters?
data.answer: Diethyl ether, being a weak donor solvent, permits the oxidation and condensation of the [Co(CO)4]- anion to afford the [Co4(CO)11]2- cluster.

data.question: What is the unique feature of the isocarbonyl bridges in compounds 1−4?
data.answer: They contain the first reported η2,μ4-CO bridges between a Ln and a transition-metal carbonyl cluster.

data.question: How does the structure of [Co4(CO)11]2- in compound 4 differ from that in compounds 1−3?
data.answer: The cluster in compound 4 has C2v symmetry and bonds to Eu(II) to generate a 1-D zigzag chain, whereas the cluster in compounds 1−3 has pseudo C3v symmetry and coordinates to Ln(II) centers, creating a 2-D sheet.

data.question: Is the [Co4(CO)11]2- cluster stable in Et2O solution?
data.answer: Yes, the [Co4(CO)11]2- cluster is stable in Et2O solution.

data.question: Does the isocarbonyl bond between Ln(II) and [Co4(CO)11]2- persist in solution?
data.answer: Yes, the isocarbonyl bonds between Ln(II) and [Co4(CO)11]2- persist in solution.

data.question: Are the basal tetrahedral cobalt atoms in compounds 1, 2, and 3 disordered?
data.answer: Yes, the basal tetrahedral cobalt atoms in compounds 1, 2, and 3 are disordered.

data.question: Is the [Co4(CO)11]2- cluster in compound 4 isoelectronic with Co4(CO)12?
data.answer: Yes, the [Co4(CO)11]2- cluster in compound 4 is isoelectronic with Co4(CO)12.

data.question: Does the formation of [Co4(CO)11]2- clusters enhance the solubility of the products in Et2O?
data.answer: Yes, the formation of [Co4(CO)11]2- clusters enhances the solubility of the products in Et2O.

data.question: Are the Ln(II) atoms in compounds 1−3 six-coordinate?
data.answer: Yes, the Ln(II) atoms in compounds 1−3 are six-coordinate.

data.question: Is the Eu(II) center in compound 4 seven-coordinate?
data.answer: Yes, the Eu(II) center in compound 4 is seven-coordinate.

data.question: Does the [Co4(CO)11]2- cluster in compounds 1−3 coordinate to Ln(II) through face-capping and edge-bridging carbonyls?
data.answer: Yes, the [Co4(CO)11]2- cluster in compounds 1−3 coordinates to Ln(II) through face-capping and edge-bridging carbonyls.

data.question: Is the [Co4(CO)11]2- cluster in compound 4 composed of a C2v symmetric cluster?
data.answer: Yes, the [Co4(CO)11]2- cluster in compound 4 is composed of a C2v symmetric cluster.

data.question: What is the role of sodium tetracarbonylcobaltate in the synthesis of [Co4(CO)11]2- clusters?
data.answer: Sodium tetracarbonylcobaltate is used as a precursor in the synthesis of [Co4(CO)11]2- clusters.

data.question: What method was used to collect single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for compounds 1, 2, 3, and 4?
data.answer: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Nonius KappaCCD diffraction system using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation.

data.question: What is the significance of the [Co4(CO)11]2- cluster in the field of organometallic chemistry?
data.answer: The [Co4(CO)11]2- cluster represents a new cluster with unique isocarbonyl bridges between a Ln and a transition-metal carbonyl cluster, expanding the understanding of cluster chemistry.

data.question: What analytical techniques were used to characterize compounds 1−4?
data.answer: Elemental analyses, infrared spectroscopy, 1H NMR, 13C NMR, and 59Co NMR spectroscopies were used to characterize compounds 1−4.

data.question: What is the impact of the solvent's nucleophilicity on the formation of [Co4(CO)11]2- clusters?
data.answer: The nucleophilicity and polarity of the solvent, such as Et2O, influence the formation of [Co4(CO)11]2- clusters by allowing oxidation and condensation of [Co(CO)4]- anions.
